item.title: claude
item.description:
KLM Apartment Application (KAA) - Insurance Application Automation#

Complete Project Context & Technical Reference

ğŸ“‹ Quick Reference#

Project Location: /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/klm-apartment-app Repository: https://github.com/emmalone/klm-apartment-app Developer: Mark (mark@emm-associates.com) Company: KLM Insurance Solutions, Inc. Last Updated: January 3, 2026

ğŸ¤– Agent Usage Best Practices#

When to Use Agents#

ALWAYS use agents for:

  • Data Extraction Tasks: Extracting data from multiple PDFs, documents, or data sources
  • Parallel Processing: When multiple independent tasks can run simultaneously
  • Complex Analysis: Deep code exploration, codebase analysis, or multi-file research
  • Domain-Specific Tasks: Tasks requiring specialized knowledge or reasoning (e.g., insurance forms, legal documents)
  • Time-Intensive Operations: Long-running tasks that benefit from background processing

Agent Types and Selection#

1. Explore Agent (Fast, codebase-focused)#

  • Use for: Finding files by patterns, searching code for keywords, understanding codebase structure
  • Thoroughness levels: “quick”, “medium”, “very thorough”
  • Example: “Explore the codebase to find all database models”

2. General-Purpose Agent (Multi-step tasks)#

  • Use for: Complex multi-step workflows, data extraction, analysis tasks
  • Best with: Sonnet model for reasoning-heavy tasks
  • Example: “Extract all data from these 5 PDF documents and consolidate findings”

3. Plan Agent (Architecture and design)#

  • Use for: Planning implementation strategies, designing system architecture
  • Returns: Step-by-step plans, identifies critical files, considers trade-offs
  • Example: “Plan the implementation of a new PDF form processing pipeline”

Parallel Agent Execution#

Maximum Efficiency Pattern:

item.title: acord_140_extraction_summary
item.description:
ACORD 140 Data Extraction Summary#

Date: January 3, 2026 Source File: /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/klm-apartment-app/source-data/Malone+140+2026.pdf Output File: /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/klm-apartment-app/data/extracted/acord_140_filled_data.json Form Version: ACORD 140 (2016/03) Form Title: Property Section - Building and Personal Property Coverage

Executive Summary#

The ACORD 140 form in the source data is primarily a blank template with minimal header information filled in. This form is intended to be completed with specific property and building details but currently only contains:

  • Date: 1/2/2026
  • Agency: KLM Insurance Solutions, Inc.
  • Named Insured: Eugene M Malone
  • Producer Signature: Brian P. Malone

No property-specific data, building details, or coverage information has been filled in.

item.title: DATABASE_WORKFLOW
item.description:
Database Workflow - Questions, Answers, and Applicant Information#

ğŸ“Š Database Overview#

The KAA database is designed to store all insurance application data in a flexible, normalized structure.

Current Status#

âœ… Database Created: kaa.db (124 KB) âœ… Field Mappings: 417 records (maps questions across forms) âš ï¸ Applicant Data: 0 records (ready to be populated)

ğŸ—ï¸ Database Structure#

Table 1: field_mappings (417 records)#

Purpose: Maps canonical field names to form-specific field names

item.title: JOTFORM_MANUAL_SETUP
item.description:
JotForm Manual Setup Guide#

Overview#

Due to API limitations with programmatically creating JotForm forms with many questions, we’ve provided multiple alternatives for collecting the missing insurance application data.

Option 1: Use the Standalone HTML Form (Recommended)#

File: output/jotform/missing_fields_form.html

Features:#

  • âœ… 88 missing fields organized by category
  • âœ… Auto-saves progress to browser localStorage
  • âœ… Downloads data as JSON on submit
  • âœ… Responsive design (works on desktop and mobile)
  • âœ… Shows which forms require each field
  • âœ… Professional styling matching KLM branding

How to Use:#

  1. Live Form (DEPLOYED):

item.title: DEPLOYMENT_SUMMARY
item.description:
HTML Form Deployment Summary#

âœ… Deployment Complete#

The KAA Insurance Application missing fields form has been successfully deployed to AWS S3.

ğŸ”— Live Form URL#

https://dev-kaa.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/forms/missing-fields.html

Alternative (HTTP only): http://dev-kaa.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/forms/missing-fields.html

ğŸ“‹ Deployment Details#

  • Date: January 2, 2026
  • Bucket: dev-kaa
  • Region: us-east-1
  • Path: /forms/missing-fields.html
  • File Size: 48.6 KB
  • Content-Type: text/html
  • Access: Public (via bucket policy)

âœ¨ Form Features#

  • 88 missing fields across 29 categories
  • Auto-saves progress to browser localStorage
  • Downloads data as JSON on submit
  • Fully responsive (desktop, tablet, mobile)
  • Professional KLM branding
  • Shows which forms require each field

ğŸ“± Access From Any Device#

The form is now accessible from:

item.title: claude
item.description:
Project Portfolio Manager - Project Context#

Desktop Application for Project Portfolio Management & Visualization

ğŸ“‹ Quick Reference#

Project Location: /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/test Developer: Mark (mark@emm-associates.com) Purpose: Desktop app for managing project portfolios with interactive bubble chart visualization Tech Stack: Python, tkinter (GUI), matplotlib (charts), pandas (data) Last Updated: January 2, 2026

ğŸ¯ Project Purpose#

A comprehensive project portfolio management tool that provides:

  • Table View: Sortable table of all projects
  • CRUD Operations: Add, edit, delete projects
  • Portfolio Visualization: Interactive bubble chart showing timeline, priority, and revenue
  • Data Persistence: CSV-based storage
  • Form Validation: Date, priority, and revenue validation

ğŸ“‚ Project Structure#

/Users/mark/PycharmProjects/test/
â”œâ”€â”€ claude.md # This file - project context
â”œâ”€â”€ main.py # Main application window and table view
â”œâ”€â”€ data_manager.py # Data persistence and CSV operations
â”œâ”€â”€ portfolio_chart.py # Bubble chart visualization window
â”œâ”€â”€ project.csv # Data file (gitignored)
â”œâ”€â”€ projectsPortfolio.py # Original single-file version (deprecated)
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt # Python dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ HelloMark.py # Test/demo file
â”œâ”€â”€ hello_world.py # Test/demo file
â”œâ”€â”€ getsetup.py # Setup utility
â””â”€â”€ README.md # User documentation

ğŸš€ Quick Start#

Installation#

cd /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/test
pip install -r requirements.txt

Run Application#

python main.py

ğŸ“Š Features#

1. Table View (main.py)#

  • Displays all projects in sortable columns:
    • Project Name
    • Start Date
    • End Date
    • Priority (1-5)
    • Status
    • Annual Revenue ($)

2. CRUD Operations#

  • Add: Click “Add Project” button
  • Edit: Double-click row or select and click “Edit”
  • Delete: Select row and click “Delete”
  • Save: Click “Save” to persist to CSV

3. Portfolio Chart (portfolio_chart.py)#

  • Bubble Visualization:
    • X-axis: Timeline (Start â†’ End dates)
    • Y-axis: Priority (1-5)
    • Bubble Size: Annual revenue
    • Bubble Color: Project status
  • Interactive Features:
    • Numbered bubbles with legend
    • Status filter dropdown
    • Hover tooltips

4. Project Statuses#

  • Active (Green)
  • Planning (Blue)
  • On Hold (Amber)
  • Completed (Gray)

ğŸ—‚ï¸ Data Structure#

CSV File: project.csv#

name,startDate,endDate,priority,status,AnnualRevenue
Website Redesign,2025-01-15,2025-06-30,5,Active,250000
Mobile App,2025-02-01,2025-12-31,4,Planning,500000

Columns:#

  • name: Project name (string)
  • startDate: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format
  • endDate: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format
  • priority: Priority level 1-5 (integer)
  • status: Project status (string, see list above)
  • AnnualRevenue: Annual revenue in dollars (float)

ğŸ”§ Technical Details#

Dependencies (requirements.txt)#

tkinter # GUI framework (built-in Python)
matplotlib # Chart visualization
pandas # Data handling
csv # CSV file operations

Key Classes#

main.py:

item.title: claude
item.description:
Sales Opportunity Manager - Project Context#

Desktop Application for Sales Pipeline Management & Visualization

ğŸ“‹ Quick Reference#

Project Location: /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/OppManagement Developer: Mark (mark@emm-associates.com) Purpose: Desktop app for managing sales opportunities with interactive bubble chart visualization Tech Stack: Python, tkinter (GUI), matplotlib (charts), pandas (data) Last Updated: January 2, 2026

ğŸ¯ Project Purpose#

A comprehensive sales opportunity management tool that provides:

  • Table View: Sortable table of all opportunities
  • CRUD Operations: Add, edit, delete opportunities
  • Pipeline Visualization: Interactive bubble chart showing timeline and priority
  • Data Persistence: CSV-based storage
  • Form Validation: Date, priority, and deal value validation

ğŸ“‚ Project Structure#

/Users/mark/PycharmProjects/OppManagement/
â”œâ”€â”€ claude.md # This file - project context
â”œâ”€â”€ main.py # Main application window and table view
â”œâ”€â”€ data_manager.py # Data persistence and CSV operations
â”œâ”€â”€ opportunity_chart.py # Bubble chart visualization window
â”œâ”€â”€ opportunities.csv # Data file (gitignored)
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt # Python dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ sampleData1.csv # Sample data for testing
â””â”€â”€ README.md # User documentation

ğŸš€ Quick Start#

Installation#

cd /Users/mark/PycharmProjects/OppManagement
pip install -r requirements.txt

Run Application#

python main.py

ğŸ“Š Features#

1. Table View (main.py)#

  • Displays all opportunities in sortable columns:
    • Company/Opportunity
    • Start Date
    • Expected Close Date
    • Priority (1-5)
    • Sales Stage
    • Deal Value ($)

2. CRUD Operations#

  • Add: Click “Add Opportunity” button
  • Edit: Double-click row or select and click “Edit”
  • Delete: Select row and click “Delete”
  • Save: Click “Save” to persist to CSV

3. Pipeline Chart (opportunity_chart.py)#

  • Bubble Visualization:
    • X-axis: Timeline (Start â†’ Close dates)
    • Y-axis: Priority (1-5)
    • Bubble Size: Deal value
    • Bubble Color: Sales stage
  • Interactive Features:
    • Numbered bubbles with legend
    • Stage filter dropdown
    • Hover tooltips

4. Sales Stages#

  • Prospecting (Gray)
  • Qualification (Blue)
  • Proposal (Yellow)
  • Negotiation (Orange)
  • Closed Won (Green)
  • Closed Lost (Red)

ğŸ—‚ï¸ Data Structure#

CSV File: opportunities.csv#

company,startDate,closeDate,priority,stage,dealValue
Acme Corp,2025-01-15,2025-03-01,5,Negotiation,150000
TechStart Inc,2025-01-20,2025-04-15,4,Proposal,75000

Columns:#

  • company: Company or opportunity name (string)
  • startDate: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format
  • closeDate: Expected close date in YYYY-MM-DD format
  • priority: Priority level 1-5 (integer)
  • stage: Sales stage (string, see list above)
  • dealValue: Deal value in dollars (float)

ğŸ”§ Technical Details#

Dependencies (requirements.txt)#

tkinter # GUI framework (built-in Python)
matplotlib # Chart visualization
pandas # Data handling
csv # CSV file operations

Key Classes#

main.py:

item.title: missing_fields_checklist
item.description:
Missing Information Checklist#

Total Missing Fields: 88

Agency Info#

  • Is this new business to your agency (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Applicant Info#

  • Applicant’s Name (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • BUSINESS PHONE # (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • Entity Type (select) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • FEIN OR SOC SEC # (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • Mailing Address (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • NAME (First Named Insured) AND MAILING ADDRESS (including ZIP+4) (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema, acord_125_schema
  • Phone # (phone) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Building History#

  • Has the building been converted from prior occupancy? If so, describe (yes_no_text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Building Info#

  • # Stories (number) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • # Units (number) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Construction Type (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is the building listed on the National Register of Historic Places or in a Historic District? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Square Footage (number) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Year Built (year) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Building Systems#

  • Are there exterior utility closets? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Building Updates#

  • Electrical (year) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • HVAC (year) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Has the property undergone a ‘Gut to Studs’ Renovation (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Plumbing (year) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Year of most recent building updates: Roof (year) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Construction#

  • Are any buildings currently under construction? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Electrical#

  • Are circuits protected by circuit breakers? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there Knob and Tube Wiring? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there any Aluminum Wiring? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Exterior#

  • Does the building have heated sidewalks (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there natural Mulch around the perimeter of the building? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Fire Safety#

  • Are fire extinguishers in all units and common areas (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • CO Detectors in all units and by all fossil fuel burning equipment (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Emergency Lighting? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Enclosed 2 Hour Fire Rated Stairways? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Fire Alarm (multi_checkbox) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Illuminated Exit Signs with Battery Backup? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Means of Egress: Two Means of Egress from all units? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Self-Closing Doors in Stairways? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Smoke Detectors: Location (multi_checkbox) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Sprinkler System (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Type (multi_checkbox) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Header#

  • AGENCY NAME (text) - Required for: acord_140_schema
  • CARRIER (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • DATE (MM/DD/YYYY) (date) - Required for: acord_140_schema, acord_125_schema
  • NAMED INSURED(S) (text) - Required for: acord_140_schema

Heating#

  • Do you have wood burning fire places or woodstoves? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Maintenance#

  • Are Snow Removal Logs Kept (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is heat maintained to at least 60 degrees in all areas of the building (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there a written winterization program in place (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Who performs the snow removal? (radio) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Management#

  • Are certs and additional insured status required of all subcontractors? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is Property Maintained By (multi_checkbox) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there a 24/7 Contact for emergencies? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Occupancy#

  • Percent Occupied (number) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Ownership#

  • Has the insured owned this location for 3 or more years (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • How many years of property ownership or property management experience does the insured have (number) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Pet Policy#

  • Are dogs permitted (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Plumbing#

  • Do you have catch basins under water heaters or washing machines? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there any Polybutylene Piping? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Policy Info#

  • PROPOSED EFF DATE (date) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • PROPOSED EXP DATE (date) - Required for: acord_125_schema

Premises Information#

  • STREET ADDRESS (text) - Required for: acord_140_schema

Producer Info#

  • ADDRESS (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • CONTACT (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • PHONE (A/C, No, Ext) (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • PRODUCER NAME (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema

Property Type#

  • Affordable/Subsidized Housing (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Assisted Living (Services provided and/or non-ambulatory) (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Boarding House (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Seasonal Property (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Senior Independent Living (No services provided and ambulatory) (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Short Term Occupancies (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Student Housing (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Roof#

  • Do you have wood shake shingles? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Safety#

  • Are grills permitted on decks or balconies? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is smoking permitted in the building or on balconies? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Security#

  • Are Security Guards used? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Are all units equipped with a deadbolt? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Security: Is there a security system? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Signature#

  • APPLICANT’S SIGNATURE (signature) - Required for: acord_140_schema, acord_125_schema
  • PRODUCER’S NAME (Please Print) (text) - Required for: acord_125_schema
  • PRODUCER’S SIGNATURE (signature) - Required for: acord_140_schema, acord_125_schema

Signatures#

  • Agent Name (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Date (date) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema, miller_supplemental_schema, acord_125_schema
  • Insured Name (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Signature (signature) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema, miller_supplemental_schema

Tenant Management#

  • Are tenants required to carry liability insurance? (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • How is tenant screening conducted (text) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there a procedure to monitor compliance with insurance requirements (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema
  • Is there a written lease in place with all tenants (yes_no) - Required for: miller_supplemental_schema

Transaction Info#

  • STATUS OF TRANSACTION (select) - Required for: acord_125_schema

item.title: README
item.description:
KLM Apartment Application (KAA)#

Insurance application automation system for commercial apartment buildings.

Overview#

KAA automates the process of completing insurance applications across multiple carriers by:

  • Extracting data from filled PDF forms
  • Storing applicant and property data in a normalized database
  • Intelligently mapping form fields to database fields
  • Auto-generating completed PDF applications
  • Maintaining historical records of all submissions

Technology Stack#

  • Backend: FastAPI + SQLAlchemy 2.0 + SQLite
  • Frontend: React with TypeScript
  • PDF Processing: pypdf, pdfplumber, ReportLab
  • Development: Poetry, Alembic, pytest
  • Deployment: AWS S3, GitHub Actions

Quick Start#

Prerequisites#

  • Python 3.11+
  • Poetry (curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -)
  • Node.js 18+ and npm
  • Git

Installation#

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/emmalone/klm-apartment-app.git
cd klm-apartment-app

# Install Python dependencies
poetry install

# Initialize database
poetry run alembic upgrade head

# Install frontend dependencies
cd frontend
npm install
cd ..

Run Locally#

# Terminal 1: Start backend
poetry run uvicorn backend.app.main:app --reload
# API will be available at http://localhost:8000
# API docs at http://localhost:8000/docs

# Terminal 2: Start frontend
cd frontend
npm start
# Frontend will be available at http://localhost:3000

Run Tests#

# Backend tests
poetry run pytest

# MVP test script
poetry run python scripts/test_mvp.py

Project Structure#

klm-apartment-app/
â”œâ”€â”€ backend/ # FastAPI backend
â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ app/
â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ main.py # FastAPI application
â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ models/ # SQLAlchemy models
â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ schemas/ # Pydantic schemas
â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ api/ # API endpoints
â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ services/ # Business logic
â”‚ â””â”€â”€ tests/ # Backend tests
â”œâ”€â”€ frontend/ # React frontend
â”‚ â””â”€â”€ src/
â”œâ”€â”€ templates/ # PDF form templates
â”œâ”€â”€ source-data/ # Source documents (not in git)
â”œâ”€â”€ output/ # Generated PDFs
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/ # Utility scripts
â””â”€â”€ alembic/ # Database migrations

MVP Scope#

Focus: Eugene Mark Malone + 2 properties (Prince Street, Middle Spring)

item.title: begin
item.description:
This project is going to be focused on creating a new application called klm-appartment-app also known as KAA. This will need a new github repo and new AWS resources, both github CLI and AWS CLI should be installed and configured.

please create a new claude.md file for this project by include all of the information needed from ..\klm-migrate\claude.md

I have included a number of documented in this

The very first thing that needs to be done is get everything configured so that I can work with the same workflow as the ..\klm-migrate project. I want to be able to develop locally as well as remotely with my iphone and deploy to new AWS buckets for dev, staging and production when this is finally completed.

item.title: MVP_SCOPE
item.description:
KAA MVP Scope - Day 1 Target#

Created: 2026-01-02
Deadline: End of day 2026-01-02

MVP Definition: Minimum Viable Product#

Goal: Demonstrate single end-to-end workflow in 8 hours

What MVP Includes (MUST HAVE)#

  1. âœ“ Database schema (3 tables: properties, applications, form_templates)

  2. âœ“ FastAPI backend with 5 endpoints:

    • POST /api/properties - Create property
    • GET /api/properties/{id} - Get property
    • POST /api/applications - Create application from property
    • POST /api/forms/upload - Upload PDF template
    • POST /api/applications/{id}/generate - Generate filled PDF

  3. âœ“ PDF Processing:

item.title: CLAUDE_CODE_INSTRUCTIONS
item.description:
Claude Code - MVP Implementation Instructions#

Objective#

Build working MVP by end of day: Single property â†’ PDF generation workflow

Autonomous Operation Mode#

  • Auto-approve: âœ“ Enabled
  • Confirm commands: âœ— Disabled
  • Max iterations: 100
  • Update CLAUDE.md every hour with progress

Implementation Order (8 Hours)#

Phase 1: Database Foundation (90 minutes)#

  1. Create backend/app/database.py:

    • SQLAlchemy async engine setup
    • SQLite connection
    • Base declarative model

  2. Create backend/app/models/property.py:

    class Property(Base):
 id, name, address_street, address_city, address_state, 
 address_zip, year_built, building_value, total_units, 
 construction_type, stories

  3. Create backend/app/models/application.py:

item.title: CONVERSATION_SUMMARY
item.description:
KAA Project - Conversation Summary & Handoff Document#

Session Overview#

Date: January 2, 2026
Participants: Mark (User), Claude (AI Assistant)
Objective: Define requirements for KLM Apartment Application (KAA) system to automate insurance application processing for commercial apartment buildings
Output: Comprehensive REQUIREMENTS.md document optimized for implementation with Claude Code

Project Context#

Business Problem#

Mark’s insurance agency (KLM Insurance) needs to automate the time-consuming process of completing insurance applications for commercial apartment buildings across multiple insurance carriers. Currently, agents manually re-enter the same data across dozens of different forms, leading to:

item.title: REQUIREMENTS
item.description:
KLM Apartment Application (KAA) - Requirements Document#

1. Executive Summary#

KAA is an insurance application automation system designed to streamline the process of completing commercial apartment building insurance applications across multiple carriers. The system extracts data from PDF forms, stores it in a normalized database, intelligently maps common fields, and auto-generates completed applications while maintaining historical records.

Primary Users#

  • Insurance agents preparing applications for commercial apartment properties
  • Multiple agents working concurrently with shared data

Version 1 Scope#

  • Standalone application (local web server)
  • SQLite database
  • No external system integration (CRM/AMS integration planned for v2)

2. Core Functional Requirements#

2.1 PDF Form Processing#

FR-001: PDF Upload and Analysis#

Priority: CRITICAL

item.title: MIGRATE_TO_GITHUB_CHECKLIST
item.description:
Migrating Website to GitHub - Safety Checklist#

BEFORE YOU START - CRITICAL SECURITY CHECKS#

â˜ Step 1: Identify Sensitive Files#

Navigate to your project directory and look for:

# Search for potential secret files
find . -name ".env*" -o -name "*.key" -o -name "*.pem" -o -name "config.php" -o -name "settings.py"

# Look for files with "password" or "secret" in them
grep -r "password\|secret\|api_key" --include="*.php" --include="*.py" --include="*.js" --include="*.env" .

Common secret files by technology:

WordPress:

  • wp-config.php (has database credentials!)
  • .htaccess (might have passwords)
  • Upload directories with customer data

Django/Python:

item.title: GITOVERVIEW
item.description:
Git & GitHub Workflow - Complete Reference Guide#

This document provides a comprehensive overview of the Git/GitHub workflow you’ve mastered through building the Task Manager API demo application.

Git Concepts You Mastered#

1. Branches#

main branch (stable)
 â””â”€ feature branch (experimental)
  • Purpose: Isolate work without affecting stable code
  • Types: main (production), feature (new work), hotfix (urgent fixes)

2. Commits#

3b18d45 - Add web interface with task table view
  • What: Snapshot of your code at a point in time
  • Hash: Unique ID (3b18d45)
  • Message: Description of what changed

3. Remote vs Local#

Local (Your Computer) Remote (GitHub)
â”œâ”€ main â”œâ”€ origin/main
â””â”€ add-web-task-table â””â”€ origin/add-web-task-table
  • Local: Your machine
  • Remote: GitHub (cloud)
  • Sync: push (upload), pull (download), fetch (check)

4. Pull Requests (PRs)#

Feature Branch â†’ Review â†’ Merge â†’ Main Branch
  • Purpose: Code review before merging
  • Benefits: Catch bugs, share knowledge, document changes
  • Process: Create â†’ Review â†’ Discuss â†’ Approve â†’ Merge

5. Fast-Forward Merge#

Before: After:
main: Aâ”€B main: Aâ”€Bâ”€Câ”€D
feature: â””â”€Câ”€D
  • Clean merge: No conflicts
  • Linear history: Easy to understand

Key Git Commands Reference#

Command What It Does When to Use
git pull origin main Download & merge latest from GitHub Start of work session
git checkout -b name Create new branch Start new feature
git status Show changed files Check what’s modified
git add <files> Stage changes for commit Prepare to commit
git commit -m "msg" Save snapshot After testing changes
git push -u origin branch Upload branch to GitHub Share your work
git fetch origin Check for updates See what’s on GitHub
git log --oneline Show commit history Review what happened
git branch -a List all branches See what exists
git branch -d name Delete local branch After merging
git remote prune origin Clean stale references After branch deletion

Additional Useful Commands#

Command What It Does
git diff Show unstaged changes
git diff --staged Show staged changes
git log --graph --oneline Visual commit history
git branch -v Show branches with last commit
git remote -v Show remote repository URLs
git checkout main Switch to main branch
git restore <file> Discard changes in file
git restore --staged <file> Unstage file

The Workflow Visualized#

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ LOCAL MACHINE (Your Computer) â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ â”‚
â”‚ 1. git pull origin main â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 2. git checkout -b add-web-task-table â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 3. Write Code (HTML, CSS, Python) â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 4. Test Locally (uvicorn app.main:app) â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 5. git add app/main.py app/templates/ app/static/ â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 6. git commit -m "Add web interface..." â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 7. git push -u origin add-web-task-table â”‚
â”‚ â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
 â”‚
 â”‚ Push
 â†“
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ GITHUB (Cloud) â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ â”‚
â”‚ 8. Create Pull Request (Web Interface) â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 9. Review Code (See Diffs) â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 10. Merge PR (Green Button) â”‚
â”‚ â†“ â”‚
â”‚ 11. Delete Branch (Cleanup) â”‚
â”‚ â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
 â”‚
 â”‚ Pull
 â†“
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ LOCAL MACHINE (Sync Back) â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ â”‚
â”‚ 12. git checkout main â”‚
â”‚ 13. git fetch origin â”‚
â”‚ 14. git pull origin main â”‚
â”‚ 15. git branch -d add-web-task-table â”‚
â”‚ 16. git remote prune origin â”‚
â”‚ â”‚
â”‚ âœ… COMPLETE CYCLE! â”‚
â”‚ â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

State Changes Throughout the Workflow#

Your Repository’s Evolution:#

Commit 1 (Initial):
â”œâ”€ app/main.py (basic API)
â”œâ”€ app/models.py
â”œâ”€ tests/test_api.py
â””â”€ README.md

 â†“ [You create feature branch]

Commit 2 (On feature branch):
â”œâ”€ app/main.py (+ web endpoint)
â”œâ”€ app/models.py
â”œâ”€ app/templates/index.html â† NEW
â”œâ”€ app/static/style.css â† NEW
â”œâ”€ tests/test_api.py
â””â”€ README.md

 â†“ [You merge PR]

Commit 3 (Merged to main):
â”œâ”€ app/main.py (+ web endpoint) âœ…
â”œâ”€ app/models.py
â”œâ”€ app/templates/index.html âœ…
â”œâ”€ app/static/style.css âœ…
â”œâ”€ tests/test_api.py
â””â”€ README.md

How This Differs with Claude Code (iPhone)#

Traditional Workflow:#

You: Write HTML â†’ Write CSS â†’ Write Python â†’ Test â†’ Debug â†’ Commit
Time: 2-3 hours

With Claude Code (What you’ll do next from iPhone):#

You: "Add a search bar to filter tasks by title"
Claude: [Reads code] [Writes HTML] [Updates CSS] [Modifies Python]
 [Adds tests] [Runs tests] [Commits] [Creates PR]
Time: 5 minutes

Key Difference:

item.title: TUTORIAL
item.description:
Task Manager API - Interactive Tutorial#

Welcome! This tutorial will teach you how to use Claude Code by practicing with this demo application. This is a working session.

What You’ll Learn#

By the end of this tutorial, you’ll know how to:

  1. Push code to GitHub
  2. Access the project from your iPhone via claude.ai/code
  3. Ask Claude to make changes
  4. Run tests automatically
  5. Create pull requests
  6. Iterate based on feedback

Part 1: Push to GitHub (Do This First - On Your Computer)#

Step 1: Create a GitHub Repository#

# Option A: Using GitHub CLI (if installed)
gh repo create demo-task-api --public --source=. --remote=origin --push

# Option B: Manual steps
# 1. Go to https://github.com/new
# 2. Repository name: demo-task-api
# 3. Description: "Learning Claude Code with a Task Manager API"
# 4. Make it Public
# 5. DO NOT initialize with README (we already have one)
# 6. Click "Create repository"
# 7. Copy the commands shown and run them:

git remote add origin https://github.com/emarkmalone/demo-task-api.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

Step 2: Verify It’s on GitHub#

Visit: https://github.com/emarkmalone/demo-task-api

item.title: README
item.description:
pytest cache directory#

This directory contains data from the pytest’s cache plugin, which provides the --lf and --ff options, as well as the cache fixture.

Do not commit this to version control.

See the docs for more information.

item.title: CLAUDE
item.description:
Claude Code Instructions#

Project: Task Manager API Demo#

Purpose#

This is a learning demo to showcase Claude Code workflows. It’s a simple REST API for task management.

Tech Stack#

  • Framework: FastAPI
  • Python Version: 3.9+
  • Testing: Pytest
  • Validation: Pydantic

Coding Standards#

Python Style#

  • Follow PEP 8
  • Use type hints for all functions
  • Keep functions small and focused
  • Maximum line length: 100 characters

Documentation#

  • Add docstrings to all public functions
  • Use Google-style docstrings
  • Keep comments clear and concise

Testing#

  • Minimum 80% code coverage
  • Test all API endpoints
  • Include edge cases and error scenarios
  • Use descriptive test names: test_<action>_<expected_result>

Development Workflow#

Running the Application#

uvicorn app.main:app --reload

Running Tests#

pytest tests/ -v --cov=app

Code Quality Checks#

# Format check
black app/ tests/ --check

# Type checking
mypy app/

# Linting
flake8 app/ tests/

API Design Guidelines#

Response Format#

All successful responses should return JSON with appropriate status codes:

item.title: CLAUDE_CODE_IPHONE_SETUP
item.description:
Claude Code Cloud Setup - iPhone Guide#

Quick Start (5 Minutes)#

Step 1: Access Claude Code on the Web#

  1. Open Safari or Chrome on your iPhone
  2. Navigate to: https://claude.ai/code
  3. Sign in with your Claude account (requires Pro, Max, or Team Premium)

Step 2: Connect GitHub#

  1. On the Claude Code web interface, look for “Connect GitHub” button
  2. Tap to authorize Claude to access your GitHub account
  3. You’ll be redirected to GitHub - tap “Authorize Claude”
  4. Install the Claude GitHub App:
    • Visit: https://github.com/apps/claude
    • Tap “Install”
    • Select which repositories Claude can access (all or specific ones)
    • Tap “Install & Authorize”

Step 3: Start Using Claude Code#

  1. Return to https://claude.ai/code
  2. Select a repository from the dropdown
  3. Type your task in the chat (e.g., “Add a README file to this project”)
  4. Watch Claude work in real-time:
    • Reading files
    • Writing code
    • Running tests
    • Creating commits
  5. Review the changes and provide feedback
  6. When satisfied, Claude can create a Pull Request

Understanding the Cloud Environment#

What Happens Behind the Scenes#

  • Execution Environment: Anthropic provides cloud VMs (virtual machines)
  • Isolated & Secure: Each session runs in an isolated container
  • GitHub Access: Claude can read your repos, create branches, and make commits
  • Terminal Access: Claude runs bash commands, tests, and builds in the cloud
  • Real-time Feedback: Just like your local terminal interaction

Comparison to Local Terminal#

Feature Local Claude Code Cloud Claude Code
Access from iPhone âŒ No âœ… Yes
Run code & tests âœ… Yes âœ… Yes
GitHub integration âœ… Yes âœ… Yes
Install dependencies âœ… Yes âœ… Yes
Create PRs âœ… Yes âœ… Yes
Network access âœ… Full âš ï¸ Limited (configurable)
Custom tools âœ… Yes âš ï¸ Limited

Advanced Setup Options#

Option A: Using Anthropic’s Cloud (Recommended for iPhone)#

No additional setup required! This is the default when you visit claude.ai/code.

item.title: README
item.description:
Project Portfolio Manager#

A desktop application for managing and visualizing your project portfolio with an interactive bubble chart.

Features#

  • Table View: View all projects in a sortable table
  • CRUD Operations: Add, edit, and delete projects
  • Data Validation: Form validation for dates, priority, and revenue
  • Portfolio Visualization: Interactive bubble chart showing projects by timeline and priority
  • CSV Persistence: All data saved to project.csv
  • Unsaved Changes Warning: Prompts before closing with unsaved changes

Installation#

Prerequisites#

  • Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)

Setup#

  1. Navigate to the project directory:
cd ~/PycharmProjects/test
  1. Install dependencies:
pip install -r requirements.txt

Usage#

Running the Application#

python main.py

Main Window#

The main window displays a table with all projects:

item.title: README
item.description:
Sales Opportunity Manager#

A desktop application for managing and visualizing your sales pipeline with an interactive bubble chart.

Features#

  • Table View: View all sales opportunities in a sortable table
  • CRUD Operations: Add, edit, and delete opportunities
  • Data Validation: Form validation for dates, priority, and deal values
  • Pipeline Visualization: Interactive bubble chart showing opportunities by timeline and priority
  • CSV Persistence: All data saved to opportunities.csv
  • Unsaved Changes Warning: Prompts before closing with unsaved changes

Installation#

Prerequisites#

  • Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)

Setup#

  1. Navigate to the project directory:
cd ~/PycharmProjects/OppManagement
  1. Install dependencies:
pip install -r requirements.txt

Usage#

Running the Application#

python main.py

Main Window#

The main window displays a table with all sales opportunities:
